awd_titl_txt: Understanding and Improving Learning from Online Mathematics Classroom Videos
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects. 

U.S. elementary teachers face many challenges.  They are asked to teach all subjects to students with different needs and abilities.  To do this well, they need good professional learning opportunities.  Many teachers look online for such opportunities, but little is known about the quality of those opportunities and how they can be improved to help teachers meet their challenges.  The goals of this project are to learn more about how teachers use one popular website for elementary mathematics teachers and how this website and similar ones can be adapted to better support teacher learning.  Specifically, the project will (1) interview teachers about their use of the website, (2) investigate how to improve the ways teachers interact with video resources on the site by testing different ways of guiding their attention, and (3) examine how teachers' interactions with these video resources are related to their students' learning of mathematics.  Findings from this project will be used to build and share effective ways to support teacher learning online.  The project will thus benefit teachers who use the popular website, teachers who use similar websites, researchers who study how teachers learn from such websites, and the students of teachers who learn from such websites.

Video-based learning has been the focus of much professional development research over the past decade.  As video-based learning has been found to be effective, many professional developers have taken this learning to scale through the online space.  A number of high profile and popular virtual learning communities (VLCs) have emerged to allow teachers to interact with video, but the scant number of studies on the effectiveness of such VLCs show some difficulties in engaging teachers in sustained, reflective professional learning.  The purpose of this project is to investigate several major issues in the design and implementation of effective VLCs for teachers and to examine the relation between teachers' reflective engagement with VLCs and their students' mathematics learning outcomes.  The investigators propose 3 studies, which build on each other, to address these issues.  This project will (1) interview teachers who are members of a popular VLC, to investigate what they learn and how they contribute to community; (2) investigate conditions that impact the posting of reflective commentary about video cases through iterative experiments, as reflective commentary has the potential to build community and to support teacher learning; and (3) investigate the relation between reflective reactions to video cases and student mathematics outcomes.  Through these investigations, this project will explore issues that impact the scalability of teachers learning asynchronously from online video.  Results will be used to develop guided pathways - a prototype of an innovation that will be based on the results from the research - on one widely used VLC.  Thus, this project will provide both a contribution to the field of STEM teacher education research and an immediate, research-based product that can be disseminated to thousands of teachers through an existing VLC.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding and Improving Learning from Online Mathematics Classroom Videos

 

Overview:

Video-based learning has shown to be effective for teacher professional learning. Thus, many professional developers have aimed to take this learning to scale via online communities that allow teachers to interact with video. Given this promise to provide supports for teachers of elementary mathematics, the purpose of this project was to investigate several issues in the design and practice of a virtual learning community (VLC), and to examine the relation between teachers? reflective engagement with videos and their students? mathematics learning outcomes. 

This project included 3 studies, building on each other, to investigate how to maximize elementary mathematics teachers? learning from video online and, ultimately, to see whether this is related to positive impacts on their students? learning outcomes. Changes were made to the VLC to improve teachers? learning experiences with the website.

 

Results Highlights:

Web analytics revealed that commentary on video posted to the VLC is often sparse and surface level, possibly indicating a lack of serious attention to the videos. However, interview data with educators indicated that they felt they learned from videos. These participants reported that the videos provided them with the opportunity to view and reflect on model lessons, plan curricula, and consider student thinking, among other learning outcomes. Participants also mentioned key factors that prevented them from posting to the site to convey their learning. These results can be used to understand how teachers perceive their own learning from classroom video and to inform effective design of the VLC and other online learning spaces.

Having a sense of community can support teacher growth in face-to-face professional development (PD). Alternatively, teachers in online, asynchronous PD might not feel a sense of community, given their physical and temporal isolation from others. Interestingly, interview data suggested that most educators considered themselves part of the community, and, importantly, saw this as a space in which to share resources. The results have implications for understanding and expanding the role of online PD in supporting professional learning.

Given the sparsity of meaningful commentary on the videos about teaching and learning mathematics on the VLC, this project examined how different prompts served to provoke educators to produce more deeply analytical commentary. Findings highlight that prompts targeted at specific focal areas (teachers, students, mathematics) produced more reflection on the respective focal areas, but focusing on one area led to relatively less reflection in other areas. These results have implications for impacting teacher reflection and coordinating online PD experiences.

This project also investigated educators? endorsement of growth mindset and its relation to their willingness to engage reflectively with elementary mathematics lesson video clips. Despite interest in how mindsets affect students as learners, relatively little research on mindset has investigated teachers as learners. Findings indicated that, for both math intelligence and teaching ability, educators? reporting of more growth mindsets was associated with higher reflection scores on the dimensions of mathematics and student thinking than teachers with more fixed mindsets. These findings suggest fostering growth mindset in PD settings could promote greater teacher reflection.

Theoretically, teachers who are deeply reflective about mathematics teaching and learning are likely to understand the importance of revealing and discussing diverse student thinking to build mathematical understanding. To investigate this, we explored the relation between teachers? reflection and their students? diversity of responses on a set of rich mathematical problems. We found a positive relation between teachers? reflection and their students? problem-solving diversity and an inverted-U-shaped relation between students? problem-solving diversity and correct solutions.  

 

Broader Impacts:

Hundreds of teachers had the opportunity to learn from their participation in the studies designed to improve their understanding and appreciation of mathematics teaching and learning. Results will inform current and future developers of online communities about the design of effective online video-based learning and will provide research-based advice on how to encourage, monitor, and assess teacher learning in the online space. Additionally, the results will likely be generalizable to the development of online learning and teacher education programs writ large.

 

Intellectual Merit:

This project directly contributes to an already healthy literature on video-based learning. It also contributes to an emerging literature base on the development of online communities for teachers. Thus far, this literature base has largely focused on designing communities for sustained participation rather than teacher learning; this study focused more on learning and thus mark a unique contribution. Finally, it contributed to broader studies of online education. As online contexts become more practical and allow broader access, it is essential to understand the ways in which principles and theories of learning might be revised. By engaging in development and analysis of how teacher learning takes place in an asynchronous, online environment, this project can also add to theories of learning, extending and transforming what we know about learning in face-to-face situations.
